body:
Hi,
I think it would help if you could you provide an example of the sql you are trying to generate.
thanks

I have two linked SQL servers Server1 and Server2. I am creating a session using Server 1. And I'm trying to specify Server2.Database.owner as an argument for schema in table_args. 
__table_args__ = {'schema': 'Server2.DB_name.owner'}. This is automatically getting converted to 'Server2.DB_nameowner'...... the '.' between db_name and owner is getting omitted automatically. Instead of passing 'Server2' to the schema argument. I am trying to see if there is any other way of using SQLAlchemy ORM to specify server name of a table.

hi there -

Per the documentation at https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/dialects/mssql.html#multipart-schema-names, SQLAlchemy currently supports two tokens at most which may be demarcated via brackets, such as `__table_args__ = {'schema': '[Server2.DB_name].[owner]'}`.     So we can render `[Server2.DB_name].owner` here.  Not sure if that's sufficient.      The "database" portion, when reflection is run, will result in an execution like "use [Server2.DB_name]".

if three individual tokens are required then we would have to implement a new feature in the SQL server dialect.
the missing dot thing is also a bug.   added #5366 for that.

**Mike Bayer** has proposed a fix for this issue in the **master** branch:

**Support multiple dotted sections in mssql schema names** https://gerrit.sqlalchemy.org/c/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/+/2020

**Mike Bayer** has proposed a fix for this issue in the **rel_1_3** branch:

**Support multiple dotted sections in mssql schema names** https://gerrit.sqlalchemy.org/c/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/+/2021
that patch should improve things but I dont have a way to test a joined-server SQL server environment, if someone knows how to do that we can test if the syntax works.
By when can we expect this bug to be fixed?

Like any open source project, when someone has time to work on it :)

Does the patch here https://gerrit.sqlalchemy.org/c/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/+/2021 solves this for you? If you could test it, it would speed things up.
I am a newbie to open source projects. Can you please provide me some guidance on how to test this patch?

If the idea is to be able to do this ...

```python
tbl = sa.Table(
    "hello", sa.MetaData(), schema="DOCKER199.mydb.dbo", autoload_with=engine
)
with engine.connect() as conn:
    result = conn.execute(tbl.select()).fetchall()
    print(result)
```

... then we're not quite there yet. PS3 in the Gerrit fails with

> sqlalchemy.exc.OperationalError: (pyodbc.OperationalError) ('08004', "[08004] [Microsoft][ODBC Driver 17 for SQL Server][SQL Server]Database 'DOCKER199.mydb' does not exist. Make sure that the name is entered correctly. (911) (SQLExecDirectW)")
> 
> [SQL: use [DOCKER199.mydb]]

And, unfortunately, it's not just the square brackets. SQL Server apparently does not let us change the database context (USE ...) to a database on a linked server:

```text
1> USE myDb
2> go
Changed database context to 'myDb'.
1> SELECT * FROM DOCKER199.mydb.dbo.hello;
2> go
txt
--------------------------------------------------
Hello from MSSQL on 192.168.0.199!

(1 rows affected)
1> USE DOCKER199.mydb
2> go
Msg 911, Level 16, State 1, Server GORD-HP\SQLEXPRESS, Line 1
Database 'DOCKER199' does not exist. Make sure that the name is entered correctly.
```

@gordthompson  propose everywhere in sql server dialect where we have "dbname, owner" we break it into three for "server, dbname, owner", then all the reflection queries would have to be altered to select for the alternate server if given.

however, can we confirm that *queries* will work with my changes.  For reflection, we can have it raise notimplemented for now when "server" is detected.

> By when can we expect this bug to be fixed?

as this is a very complex change, full support will be delayed.

you can solve your problem right now by creating synonyms to refer to the schemas and tables in this alternate database, then use those names in your SQLAlchemy models:

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/synonyms/synonyms-database-engine?view=sql-server-ver15

> can we confirm that _queries_ will work with my changes

For ORM queries the square brackets as currently rendered are problematic:

```python
engine = sa.create_engine(
    r"mssql+pyodbc://@localhost:49242/myDb?driver=ODBC+Driver+17+for+SQL+Server",
    echo=True,
)

Base = declarative_base()


class Hello(Base):
    __tablename__ = "hello"
    __table_args__ = {"schema": "DOCKER199.mydb.dbo"}
    txt = sa.Column(sa.String(50), primary_key=True)

    def __repr__(self):
        return f"<Hello(txt={self.txt})>"


Session = sessionmaker(bind=engine)
session = Session()

for instance in session.query(Hello):
    print(instance)
```

> sqlalchemy.exc.ProgrammingError: (pyodbc.ProgrammingError) ('42S02', "[42S02] [Microsoft][ODBC Driver 17 for SQL Server][SQL Server]Invalid object name 'DOCKER199.mydb.dbo.hello'. (208) (SQLExecDirectW)")
>
> [SQL: SELECT [DOCKER199.mydb].dbo.hello.txt AS [DOCKER199_mydb_dbo_hello_txt] 
FROM [DOCKER199.mydb].dbo.hello]

That is,

```text
1> SELECT [DOCKER199.mydb].dbo.hello.txt AS [DOCKER199_mydb_dbo_hello_txt] FROM [DOCKER199.mydb].dbo.hello
2> go
Msg 208, Level 16, State 1, Server GORD-HP\SQLEXPRESS, Line 1
Invalid object name 'DOCKER199.mydb.dbo.hello'.
```

Sadly, "fixing" the square brackets causes another issue

```text
1> SELECT [DOCKER199].[mydb].dbo.hello.txt AS [DOCKER199_mydb_dbo_hello_txt] FROM [DOCKER199].[mydb].dbo.hello
2> go
Msg 4104, Level 16, State 1, Server GORD-HP\SQLEXPRESS, Line 1
The multi-part identifier "DOCKER199.mydb.dbo.hello.txt" could not be bound.
```

so it looks like we might have to resort to generating a table alias if one is not specified

```text
1> SELECT alias1.txt AS [DOCKER199_mydb_dbo_hello_txt] FROM [DOCKER199].[mydb].dbo.hello AS alias1
2> go
DOCKER199_mydb_dbo_hello_txt
--------------------------------------------------
Hello from MSSQL on 192.168.0.199!
```
@gordthompson , can you try to use the patch in the above gerrit and set the schema name as:  `[DOCKER199].[mydb].[dbo]`  ? that's how it should work
also if this is truly not workable then we should recommend synonyms as the way to go for this case.   wont support reflection

Still with PS3 in Gerrit_2020:

```Python
engine = sa.create_engine(
    r"mssql+pyodbc://@localhost:49242/myDb?driver=ODBC+Driver+17+for+SQL+Server",
    echo=True,
)

Base = declarative_base()


class Hello(Base):
    __tablename__ = "hello"
    __table_args__ = {"schema": "[DOCKER199].[mydb].[dbo]"}
    txt = sa.Column(sa.String(50), primary_key=True)

    def __repr__(self):
        return f"<Hello(txt='{self.txt}')>"


Session = sessionmaker(bind=engine)
session = Session()

for instance in session.query(Hello):
    print(instance)
```

> sqlalchemy.exc.ProgrammingError: (pyodbc.ProgrammingError) ('42000', "[42000] [Microsoft][ODBC Driver 17 for SQL Server][SQL Server]Incorrect syntax near '_'. (102) (SQLExecDirectW)")

```text 
[SQL: SELECT [DOCKER199].[mydb].dbo.hello.txt AS [[DOCKER199]_[mydb]_[dbo]_hello_txt] 
FROM [DOCKER199].[mydb].dbo.hello]
```

The square brackets are not escaped inside the (square-bracketed) column alias. T-SQL requires that the *closing* square brackets be doubled-up ...

```text
1> SELECT QUOTENAME('[DOCKER199]_[mydb]_[dbo]_hello_txt') AS quoted;
2> go
quoted
----------------------------------------------------------
[[DOCKER199]]_[mydb]]_[dbo]]_hello_txt]
```
... but even with the "corrected" column alias the query doesn't fly

```text
1> SELECT [DOCKER199].[mydb].dbo.hello.txt AS [[DOCKER199]]_[mydb]]_[dbo]]_hello_txt] FROM [DOCKER199].[mydb].dbo.hello
2> go
Msg 4104, Level 16, State 1, Server GORD-HP\SQLEXPRESS, Line 1
The multi-part identifier "DOCKER199.mydb.dbo.hello.txt" could not be bound.
```

so we're back to

```text
1> SELECT alias1.txt AS [[DOCKER199]]_[mydb]]_[dbo]]_hello_txt] FROM [DOCKER199].[mydb].dbo.hello AS alias1
2> go
[DOCKER199]_[mydb]_[dbo]_hello_txt
--------------------------------------------------
Hello from MSSQL on 192.168.0.199!

(1 rows affected)
```

Are we having fun yet?

**Mike Bayer** referenced this issue:

**Support multiple dotted sections in mssql schema names** https://gerrit.sqlalchemy.org/c/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/+/2020
